text: It is known that <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a potent growth factor and may therefore favor the proliferation of <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - cells and thus decrease the relative percentage of <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + cells .

However , analysis of cell division kinetics by CFSE-labeling demonstrated that <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> did not differentially promote cell growth of <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + over that of <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - .
In fact both populations showed similarly enhanced proliferation ( Figure 6A ) .

Furthermore the <extra_id_0> TGF-beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated induction of <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression was not caused by overgrowth of a <extra_id_0> CD25 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + minority , since the number of <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + cells was low / absent in the purified <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + <extra_id_0> CD45RA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells ( between 0 % and 1 % ) , and the <extra_id_0> FOXP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + cells were not confined to the highly divided cells .
